reviewText: Recalling this excellent series from when it was originally broadcast I purchased it after havng read the Amazon reviews of this set. Though mentioned in other reviews, there is no explanation as to why the entire series of all 34 episodes does not include the theme song associated with the show. The song is readily available on goggle and elsewhere. Perhaps it is a question of copyright royalties and Timeless Video was unwilling to play, though on their website they list the series at over $34.00.. I also feel that Timeless video was a bit less than candid claiming the set included the entire series, but did not mention the exceptionally poor quality  of “The Gun that killed Lincoln” until one second before it started to play with a brief slide explanation--so fast that one needs to hit the pause button to read its contents. The picture quality of that episode is a "1" star." There is, however, yet  another problem that should have never happened.The credits at the end of several episodes (specifically the third panel) was identical, repeated again and again.The first panel of credits has Jock Mahoney as Yancy Derringer. The second panel has Kevin Hagen as John Colton and X. Brands as Pahoo-Ka-Ta-Wah..The third panel is supposed to list the guest stars for that particular episode. Several episodes (#24–28) from the “The Gun That Murdered Lincoln” through and including “Collector's Item,” “Fire on the Frontier,” “Duel at the Oaks,” and “The Wayward Warrior” have the same identical third panel – with NONE of the correct guest actors listed. I have not seen the episodes beyond that. The problem may well continue through to the last episode 34. I wrote to Timeless Video and received a short reply which in effect stated "that is the way we got them and that's the way we produced them." Certainly if Timeless Video could insert an "explanation" slide (card) about the "Gun that shot Lincoln" episode, it could have inserted the correct (third) credit cards for the episodes I mentioned. The cast information is readily available on TV episode Guide among other sources. For the sake of accurate TV history such errors should never have gotten through.. The information is available. I guess the bottom line costs and profit margin  prevented a total 5 star product from being made and released. I wonder if the above is part of the reason for Amazon dumping its stock on December 5 (“Movie & TV deals) for $13.49 -- almost one-third the Timeless retail price? I will be very wary of other Timeless Video products.
summary: Less than meets the eye at first glance
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off, I'm watching Yancey Derringer with an Epson Powerlite 93+ projector on a 50" Da-lite wall screen.I watched this series a child in re-runs circa 1965-66 and I wasn't sure what I would think of it now. Having watched seven episodes so far, I can say it is a fine, fun series with good plots, good acting and interesting guest stars and co-stars. Speaking of which, Frances Bergen, mother of Candace Bergen, is very good in the series. Others reviewers complain about the sound, but all I'm using is the projector's built in speaker and I have had no problem. Sure, it may look a bit washed out once on a while, but this is from 1958-59 and source elements have worn a bit in fifty-five years. Probably the original negatives are long gone. We can either complain that this doesn't look as good my Twilight Zone blu-ray set, or we can be glad that the complete run of 34 episodes has survived at all. Personally, I vote for the latter! Yancy Derringer and Disney's live-action Zorro series, from the same period, both have class. Of course the Zorro episodes had much, much more money poured into them, but in this case Yancey Derringer makes up for a smaller budget with creativity and class. If you are hesitating getting this series, don't! I'm going to continue to enjoy watching it!

reviewText: When I researched Jock Mahoney and found that he was a stuntman and did his own stunts, well it just made the show even better.  Purchased based on reviews and fell in love with it and all the actors. I felt Yancy Derringer started it all for Jim West, Bond, and any riverboat gambler type.  I have turned my friends on to Yancy Derringer and they all love it.  You forget about it being black and white and any sound problems are just for a few seconds.  I felt that for the age of the film it was put on DVD pretty darn good. The light fingered Jody is one of my favorites.  The guest stars are wonderful and it takes a few minutes to remember them as they are so young on this show (at least to me).  I started with the dvd that had 17 shows and quickly ordered the entire series.  I cannot believe it did not last longer. Highly recommend this show.

reviewText: "Yancey Derringer" is a fast paced western series with an unusual hero- a rogue who actually works on the side of the law and administers justice in very creative ways. He comes off as a dandy and at times a sophisticated blue blood. But Yancey is able to straddle the fence between the seamy side of New Orleans and the wealthy gentry and integrate with both philosophies. In certain ways, Yancey is a forerunner of James West  (minus the sci-fi scenarios) as an intrepid secret agent.  However Yancey ( and his sidekick Pahoo) can effortlessly blend in New Orleans society with greater ease and panache. The series deserved to go beyond 34 episodes.
summary: Yancey Derringer- Rogue with a Heart For Justice.

reviewText: I grew up watching this and other TV series.  I was fascinated by a gambler gunslinger who used derringer pistols - yes, plural, including ine in his hat.  His companion, Pahoo, whose full name means "Wolf Who Stands In Water," was the butt of a joke with Pahoo translating as "Wet Wolf or Dog".  It was also interesting that Pahoo spoke only through sign language and carried a short barreled shotgun under the blanket perpetually draped ever his shoulder.Set in New Orleans during the post - Civil War/War of Northern Aggression Reconstruction Era gives a view, slanted for the TV standards and entertainment purposes, of that historical period.Yancy Derringer may be dated for some tastes, but I don't think the entertainment value is decreased significantly.

reviewText: YANCY DERRINGER AND THE WOLF WHO STANDS IN WATER BLASTS WITH SAM PECKINPAH SHOTGUN IMPACT ON DVD.Jock Mahoney leaves the Range Rider far behind and strides in ruffles and brocadeswith his sawed-off shotgun weilding Pawnee guard standing their ground in post Civil War New Orleans.I never thought I'd see the TV series Yancy Derringer, with Jock and X Brands on DVD on printslooking as spiffy as Yancy in his ruffled shirts and brocades.I never thought every episode with Pahoo Ka Ta Wah (Pawnee for Wolf Who Stands In Water)firing his double-barreled shotgun and blowing bodies,Sam Peckinpah style,up off the floor and slamming into walls or hurtling over tables released in a Complete Series set,chronologically in order on disc, with all the unusual amount of continuity of the series intact.And yes I know there are some who believe Pahoo's name is with a "Ke" rather than a "Ka",and may be right,but almost every source written about the character has it the other way.Every episode from the series is in this set, UNCUT, and with the exception ofThe Gun That Murdered Lincoln in the sharpest prints I have ever seen on thisseries.[...]The themesong with the lyrics aren't on these prints.  It's the only downside, and Iwrite about this at length in the longer interview.  "They say that Yancy Derringerhad ruffles at his wrists, brocades and silver buckles, and iron in his fists."You can read the complete review for Yancy and Pahoo on COMICS BULLETIN,about here, and even see photos of both in action, and even at leastone photo of Jock as the Range Rider.Look forward to your reactions.Hopefully visitors there who have never heard of the series will come hereor to Timeless and check it out, and maybe help sell the DVD set!Don McGregor
summary: YANCY DERRINGER AND THE WOLF WHO STANDS IN WATER BLASTS WITH SAM PECKINPAH SHOTGUN IMPACT ON DVD.

He is shadowed by a Native American Chief throughout who never speaks verbally but only uses sign.  The main character only uses a Deringer ergo the name.  I did not intiially like the show as it is not set in the west but after you watch the entire series it is OK, just different.  You do know you are watching an early TV show though, the DVD has that feel of an early soap.

reviewText: I rather liked this show as a 10-year old in 1958.  Surprisingly, I like it just as much now.  The show is fast-paced and well written.  Jock Mahoney (the star) was an ex-stuntman and does his own stunts in the show--some of them quite spectacular.  Guest stars from the period--Nick Adams, Charles Bronson, Louise Fletcher add a special touch to the show's entertainment--some are almost unrecognizable!Picture quality (save one episode) is very good and I would recommend this to anyone interested in action, adventure, and mid-century westerns!
summary: Still works for the grown-up child in me!

reviewText: When a Birmingham, Alabama TV station began showing Yancy Derringer weekday afternoons in 1961, it was almost enough to cause this young man to fail the fifth grade due to truancy.  I was first introduced to the show courtesy of  a case of German Measles.  While bored one afternoon waiting for the red spots to go away, I turned on the TV set and became mesmerized by Yancy and his sidekick, Pahoo.I was awestruck by the clever concealment of Yancy's weapon of choice...the derringer.  There was one up his fancy white sleeve, one up his white britches leg and who would have thought of hiding one in his white pillbox crown gambler's  hat.  The latter was immensely valuable since every western hero could count on being  surprised at least once from behind and knocked senseless by the villain's six-gun.  Not  Yancy,  the derringer always "cushioned"  the blow from above.  At least that made sense when I was 11.And that Pahoo!  Took no prisoners.  He had this long  knife in a scabbard over his shoulder.  In a fraction of a second, he could send it down range and  have it buried to the hilt  before nemesis Jack Elam could focus with his good eye.  And if, by chance,  15 inches of steel  buried in your chest wasn't enough, Pahoo always kept the sawed-off shotgun under his serape-looking-thing and could pump out more ground meat than McDonald's .I always tried to mimic the hand signals Pahoo would use, since he never talked.  Yancy could carry on a conversation with Pahoo and Pahoo would always respond with one or two hand signals.  Needless to say, conversations were short, as were the gunfights.  After all, they were derringers , you know.There were favorite episodes, like the one where some outlaw dared to dress like Yancy and rob banks.  He had this Pahoo lookalike too.  I always got spooked by that one because I kept imagining what  two Pahoos could do to each other.  Then there was the episode at Christmas when Yancy sings, I believe,  "Dixie"  to the children in an orphan's home.  Imagine a hero doing that now.  The PC police would go Pahoo, or er...postal.I've read a number of articles about the series and why it was canceled after only one season.  There were problems with their bread sponsor and  their air time was opposite another popular show.  Nonetheless, I'm looking forward to seeing it again.  I just hope it looks as good on a 60-inch Sony as it did back then on our 19-inch Zenith Black and white.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sadly, you won't hear that wonderful theme song on these discs - I guess they didn't want to pay the licensing fee. Despite that, the shows are just as enjoyable as I remember them from when I was a kid. I love the interaction of Yancy and his Native American friend Pahoo, and the humor reminds me of the best of the Maverick shows. Jock Mahoney is perfect as Yancy. I loved him in the show as an 8 year old and I still do. I've been waiting for many years for this show to be available either on Netflix or on TV Land or some such. When I saw the entire show was available at Amazon on DVD, I bought it right away. I don't know why this show lasted just one season. But at least back then, seasons were 34-39 episodes long (summer reruns truly were just that) so you have a chance to watch what would today be 2 seasons of shows. "...on every danger trail, On riverboat, in manor house, And now and then in jail." Actually, Yancy spends a lot of time in jail, that's part of the running joke on the show. Best $20 I've spent in a while. I viewed some of the episodes with my mom on a recent visit with her and we both laughed and enjoyed them immensely. Yancy was like a New Orleans James Bond before James Bond made it to the movies. BTW, Jock Mahoney started his career as a stunt man and does many of his own stunts in the show. He also was the oldest actor to date to play Tarzan in movies (he made 2 of them). If you remember the show from the late 50s, this is a must buy, and if you just want to watch a fun show from that era, you won't go wrong.

reviewText: You get to be a certain age--old--and you yearn to see some of the old TV shows from your youth. Thanks to COZI and ANTENNA TV and DVD's a lot of those shows have become available. If your watching on TV you catch a couple of episodes and realize just how bad the acting and writing were. The reaction is worse if you bought a few seasons only to realize at twelve your critical viewing skills were minimal at best. However there are a few that not only live up to your memory but surpass your expectations and Yancy Derringer is one of those like Maverick. The writing was smart, the plots interesting, and the acting remarkably good. Jock Mahoney is fine as the lead and X Brands steals scenes even though he never speaks. I have a suspicion the success of the series owes much to the writing, producing, and directing team of Richard Sale and Mary Loos who apparently had total control over their collaboration. It's unfortunate this series ended after only one year. My wife suggested Sale and Loos may have divorced and that caused the demise. They did divorce but I have no idea when but regardless they did create a memorable show that still holds up. Another reason may have been the inclusion of A list character actors of that period including John Dehner, Robert Rockwell, Gene Evans, Dennis Patrick, Charles Maxwell, Ray Danton, Marie Windsor, Bill Williams, Claude Akins, John Qualen, and Robert Lowery to list a few. It was a rare episode that didn't include someone of contemporary note. If you watch, I believe you will be quite satisfied especially if you are of a certain age.

reviewText: Old western type series set in New Orleans.Yancy Derringer is a suave , sophisticated dude who is has friends on both sides of the law.As such he is valuable to the Administrator of New Orleans(sort of like the mayor) to do undercover work in the best interests of the city.He has a best friend that never talks . An Indian whose name in English means Wolf Who Walks On Water. They communicate with sign language.And he gets into all kinds of adventures both personal and for the city.Jock Mohoney is excellent and the stories are too.I highly recommend this series to anyone liking good old fashioned adventure stories  !

reviewText: This series starred Jock Mahoney,Sally Field's step-father,as Yancy Derringer, a river boat gambler who works for the Administrator of New Orleans played by Kevin Hagen, better known as Doc Baker on "Little House on the Prairie" with his indian side-kick Pahoo played by an actor named X Brands.Lots of action as Jock Mahoney was once also a stuntman.A good solid series that unfortunately only ran for one season.I enjoyed watching this little series with it's exciting and interesting stories of life in the murky underworld of New Orleans.Death waits around every corner and alleyway.Thee seems to be some question of the theme song.When I watched it in re-runs on TV it had the same enjoyable music that is on these disc's.I didn't know of or heard one with lyrics.Guest stars include:Jim Davis,Jock Ewing from Dallas,Charles BronsonLouise Fletcher Nurse Ratchid in "One flew over the Cuckoo's Nest"Claude AkinsRay DantonNick Adams "The Rebel"All 34 episodes are filmed in Black and White.
summary: Way Down Yonder in New Orleans

reviewText: Now, I'd heard all about Yancy from my brothers and my parents growing up but there were no dvd's in existence then and it wasn't in syndication. I mean I wanted it but I wasn't going to pay too high a price because, shudder the thought, but what if I didn't like the series right?  Never fear, it is quite enjoyable and that fact that it takes place in my beloved New Orleans, well that's the icing on the cake.  Good stories and I think his Native American protector is Chewbacca cool.  Jock Mahoney plays the character with class and Kevin Hagen, remember him from Little House on the Prairie and many other westerns, ususally the store keeper or the villain, and the normal retinue of TV stars passing through. I'm not finished watching them all becasue I'm staggering my viewing to make the experience last longer.The shipping and packaging was up to normal Amazon standards, keep it up and the Postal Service is getting them to me earlier than stated in the shipping.  I'm not complaining mind you!

reviewText: I am a big Jock Mahoney fan so I  had to buy this.  But I had never seen it  before.  The show is good.  Yance is a southern gentlemen type, like Rehet Butler.  He is an unofficial undercover man for  the city of New Orleans.  His boss is played by Kevin Hagen, who spent part of two seasons chasing little people in the TV show Land of the Giants.  Yance is accompanied by his faithful indian friend, Pahoo-Ka-a-Wa,  who never speaks and uses sign language. He is also very  handy with his knives.  Yancy and Pahoo fight various bad guys ranging from pirates and murderers to suave gentlemen  gamblers and their ladies of ill repute.  Yancy is sent out on undercover missions by  his boss.  Now for the bad news.  The show is boxed in  plastic case, two disk set inside each inside sleeve.  No book.  No listing.  Nothing.  No extras at all.  The episodes are listed on the disk but the disk are not numbereed so, unless you know the show you dont know which disk is 1 - 4. Jock also starred in the  show The Range Rider.  Another  great TV western.  He can also be seen in several 3 stooges shots in the early 50's.

reviewText: I remember seeing these shows as a young teenager, and enjoyed the suave, confident character portrayed by Jock Mahoney.  Along with the unwavering loyalty of his Pawnee friend, Pahoo.  The video and audio quality on these DVDs is excellent.  There is only a very minor error, that a real video afficianado would detect:  Pahoo's name is spelled out in the online description and on the video sleeve as "Pahoo-Ka-Ta-Wah"  which is not how Yancy pronounces his friend's name.  The correct way to introduce his loyal sidekick is:  Pahoo-Ka-Te-Wah; with the third part of the name pronounced like the drink  TEA .  Regardless of this trivia buff material, I couldn't be happier with the collection.  There are a few recognizable stars in the series:  Frances Bergen, Claude Akins, Charles Bronson, Beverly Garland, plus a few more.  Example of the better acting in old time TV.  Classic B&W  TV at its best.

reviewText: Had bought a compilation of this great series a year ago and while happy with the content, this short lived series was a favorite of mine as a kid, the presentation in terms of picture and sound quality was severely lacking. Timeless Media Group has righted that wrong with a well crafted presentation and this offering provides the entire series, while the other, only half of the mere 34 episodes. And at 34 episodes it should have lasted longer. Highly recommend for the uninitiated. And for those that caught it the first time around more than 50 years ago - like seeing an old friend after a very long while.
